results.title: Olympic glory the golden years: Aussies and Kiwis in sport
results.creator_credit: James Murray, Golden Years and Denis Phelan
results.brief_description: Featuring remarkable achievements from athletes the like of; Betty Cithbert, Australai’s “Golden Girl” who was only 18 when she smashed the Olympic record for the 100m dashand took home three gold medals; Dawn Fraser, the first Olympic swimmer of either sex to win the same event three times; Raelene Boyle, the super sprinter twice runner-up in the 200m track event, beaten by world record wins each time,; and Jack Lovelock who scored an incredible victory in one of the most hotly contested 1500m finals in Olympic history. Porduction based on the Big Fights Olympic library.

results.title: Olympic Games, Melbourne, Australia, 1956
results.brief_description: The 1956 Olympics warranted the Straford Brothers using their cherished stock of coloured film to capture this unique event. Original footage of the Athletics field (notably pole vaulting), swimming and diving events in the pool have been compiled by Frank years later with additional video content and a voiceover. Despite shooting some of this additional footage on his living room floor (inadvertantly including a glimpse of shagpile carpet) and such ‘special effects’ as a whiteboard marker illustrating points on a map, the documentary has a lot of interesting detail about the event; about their personal experience of it and the novelty of seeing OB Television crews in action.

results.title: Olympic Games, 1960, Rome = La Grande olimpiade
results.creator_credit: Cineriz, Realiegato dall'Institute Nationale and Romolo Marcellini
results.brief_description: After the arrival of the Olympic torch from Greece, and a short history of the Games, Pope John welcomes the athletes and the Games are opened in an impressive ceremony. Interspersed between the various events are glimpses of the tourists and competitors. Includes Herb Elliott’s world record and olympic record, Dawn Fraser’s world record and Australia winning the cross-country riding event. The final highlights are the great marathon and the closing ceremony.

results.title: Olympic games 1956
results.brief_description: A survey of Melbourne Olympic Games; opening by the Duke of Edinburgh; arrival of the Olympic torch carried by Ron Clarke; Olympic oath taken by John Landy. Highlights of events. Closing ceremony in which athletes took part for the first time as individuals.

results.title: Olympic Games-Seoul 1988
results.brief_description: The 1988 Summer Olympic Games in Seoul have been called the greatest of the modern era. As 160 nations competed in 23 sports for no less than 237 gold medals, the Olympic ideals of international goodwill and sporting excellence touched the world. The Golden Moments is an official highlights video of the Games.

results.title: Olympic fragments
results.brief_description: Commissioned for the 1980 Winter Olympic Games in Lake Placid, New York, Olympic Fragments is a taut, expressive reinterpretation of athletic movement, a tour-de-force of dynamic editing and post-production techniques. Through sophisticated visual and aural juxtapositions, Fitzgerald and Sanborn isolate the gestures and movements of athletes in a controlled, powerful display. Eschewing the ‘thrill of victory’ tradition of broadcast television sports coverage, they allow a portrait of individual skill and grace under pressure to emerge from their manipulation of highly fragmented and choreographed imagery — what they term the ‘skill, beauty and sheer joy of kineticism.’

results.title: Olympic Century : the Olympic Spirit
results.creator_credit: Transworld International, Dirk Glaser, Thomas Lewis and Stewart Binns
results.brief_description: This video tells the story of the Modern Olympic Games. From the humble beginnings in 1896 to the most widely watched television extravaganza in the world, there has been a fascinating, dramatic and at times controversial journey. It opens with a dramatic overview of the entire Olympic spectacle and then goes on to explore the rediscovery of the heritage of the ancient world in the 19th century and how the games came to be inspired by the ancient games. It also looks at the celebration of the Olympic festival and how the games have grown to become what they are today.

results.title: Olympia: the film of the XI Olympic Games. Part II
results.brief_description: Part two from Leni Riefenstahl’s “Olympia”, a record of the Berlin Games of 1936 and an elegy on the youth of 1936, dedicated to the highest ideals of sportsmanship. In this part, Riefenstahl focusses on the aesthetics of the young virile body of the athletes creating a visual poetry in motion.

results.title: Olympia: the film of the XI Olympic Games, Berlin, 1936
results.brief_description: The official record of the XIth Olympiad held in Berlin in 1936. Beginning with a long series of classic figures depicting athletics in ancient Greece, the film continues with the bearing of the Olympic torch across the Continent of Europe to Berlin, where entry into the Reich Sport Field introduces the sections of the film recording the actual events. The “Olympiad” is a majestically conceived and executed film recording not only the sporting contests but also rendering eternal on film the charms of athletic sports, their special beauties, their grace and their power. This great film captures for all time the spirit of those sixteen glorious days when the Olympic flame burned on the arena, the bell tolled and the world’s best athletes measured their strength in stirring combat. Perhaps it is hard to forgive Leni Riefenstahl her collusion with the Nazis, but neither can we deny the inspired lyricism of her cine-spectacles. Extraordinary and inspired throughout, this film’s testament to the State’s power to colonise even beauty and poetry. Music by Herbert Windt. Commentary in German.
